title: Information required when using online benefit calculators
displayTitle: Information required when using online benefit calculators
body:
Online benefit calculators will likely request the following information - so do ensure the person you are supporting has this to hand before starting a calculation: 

  • Income details (for example, benefits, earnings from employment, tax credits and pensions) 
  • Whether the claimant is married, in a civil partnership or co-habiting (income details of their partner will also be required)
  • Details of anyone living with the claimant 
  • Any savings or investments 
  • Any tax bills 
  • Rent or mortgage payments 
  • Whether the claimant or anyone else in the household receives carer’s allowance. 

Everyone’s situation is different and eligibility for benefits is dependent on their individual needs.

Note: be sure to view 'Universal Credit' and 'Most Common Benefits' two resources available in the menu.

title: About
body:
Five partner agencies from the advice and support practitioner community in Scotland worked with Shelter Scotland and The Money & Pensions Service to develop this Money Supporter Training.

 

A total of 50 individuals have been involved in the co-design process, contributing their own knowledge and experience to the information and resources within. 

 

The training product is intended to be piloted with 250 individuals upon its release nationally.

title: Money Supporter Training
body:
Money Supporter Training is structured in the following way: 

  1. 6 topics including; Welfare benefits, Budgeting, Savings, Planning for later life, Debt solutions and Borrowing are covered in the following six pages.  

  1. Each topic is introduced by participants from partner agencies who have been involved in the co-design process. 

  1. Accompanying resources are included within each topic of Money Supporter Training which you can download to assist you with the work you do.

title: Benefits review
body:
If the person you support does not agree with a benefit decision, they can request a mandatory reconsideration. If they still don’t agree, they can make an appeal.

The GOV.UK appeal process is as follows: 

  • Before submiting an appeal you must ask for a benefits decision to be looked at again - this is called 'mandatory reconsideration' 
  • Appeals can be made to the tribunal within a month of getting the result of a mandatory reconsideration decision
  • Once an appeal has been submitted a person can provide evidence to the tribunal
  • Appeals are decided at a tribunal hearing.

The GOV.UK appeals process explained step-by-step

Note: Citizens Advice Scotland also provide excellent support to guide people through a benefits appeal process.

title: Key points
body:
• People you support may need to understand what benefits are available to them to stabilise their situation. Or to deal with a change in circumstance which could effect their benefits.
  • Support someone to calculate their entitlement to benefits by using an online benefit calculator.
  • Explain the eligibility features of the most common benefits including universal credit.
  • Know what grants may be available and local services in your area.
  • A benefit decision is not forever if new information becomes available.

title: Case study
body:
Situation

Mary has reduced mental capacity and lives in supported accommodation. At her weekly support meeting with her support worker Danny, she appears extremely anxious and Danny asks her why. She tells him she has not received benefits for over 3 weeks and her rent is due. He asks her if she has had any letters or telephone calls recently and establishes that she received some confusing letters from the DWP a few weeks ago. After reading the letters, he explains to Mary that her benefits have stopped due to her failure to return a limited capability for work questionnaire. He explains this can easily be sorted out and asks her if its okay for him to refer her to their in-house Money Advice service.

Support provided   

Danny offered to accompany Mary to her appointment where the money adviser liaises with the DWP and negotiates to have Mary’s ESA claim re-opened. The money advisor also liaises with the housing benefit and council tax team and the clients housing officer to explain the situation and ensure that her housing benefit is reinstated to avoid any rent arrears. Mary has enough money for food for a few days so foodbank vouchers were not required. Danny supports Mary to return her capability for work questionnaire and meets with her regularly to monitor the situation.

Outcome

Danny’s understanding of benefits and strong communication skills enabled him to quickly diagnose Mary’s problem. He recognised how important it was to get her benefits reinstated and accurately refer Mary for Money Advice. His knowledge of welfare benefits will help him to monitor and support Mary.

title: Budgeting benefits
body:
Budgeting benefits include:

  • Being able to spot areas where savings can be made
  • Less likely to end up in debt
  • Less likely to get caught out by unexpected costs
  • More likely to have a good credit rating
  • More likely to be accepted for a mortgage or loan
  • Being in a good position to save up for a holiday or another treat.

Most people can see the benefits if they are explained in a simple way that is relevant to their situation.

title: Creating a budget
body:
Creating a budget involves adding up all outgoings and all income. 

The outgoings are then subtracted from the income. 

What’s left is the person’s budget for the week or month.

Select through the following example in the slides:

_items.title: Total monthly income
_items.body:
Total monthly income = £1800 

The full amount of money brought into the home each month. 

This should include any benefits and maintenance payments.

_items.title: Total monthly expenses
_items.body:
Total monthly expenses =  £1300 

The full amount you spend each month on rent, fuel, loans and food for example.

_items.title: Amount left over
_items.body: Amount left over or deficit =  £500

title: Budget planners
body:
These handy resources can help you to track outgoings:

  • Budget planner
  • Money Saving Expert budget planner
  • Online budget planner

Budget plans should be thorough and include all outgoings. Amounts included in the budget plan should be realistic to give an accurate picture of what is affordable. 

Remember to include the infrequent expenses such as:

  • Vet bills
  • Birthday and Christmas presents.

It is common to underestimate these expenditures:

  • Clothing
  • Presents
  • Children’s pocket money
  • Hair cuts
  • Pet food
  • Footwear
  • Childcare.

title: Before completing a budget planner
body:
The following should be gathered:

  • Payslips
  • Any benefits received
  • Bills
  • Bank statements
  • Receipts
  • Credit card statements.

title: Steps to create a budget
Maximising income
body:
There are organisations in Scotland who can offer an income maximisation service. 

They can:

  • Complete checks for benefit entitlement
  • Complete benefits forms
  • Can provide or refer for specialist advice on debt and fuel poverty
  • Check tax issues for example, allowances and how much should be paid. 

Other ideas to increase income: 

  • If able to work, look for a job or second job
  • Sell unwanted goods
  • Rent out a room (seek the permission of a landlord if the accommodation is rented).

title: Income maximisation services
body:
Citizens Advice ScotlandMoney Saving Expert

title: How to help the people you support stick to a budget plan?
displayTitle: How to help the people you support stick to a budget plan?
body:
Staying on track

  • Offer to review their budget planner at regular times to see how they are getting on
  • If they have difficulty sticking to a monthly budget, suggest they change it to a weekly budget
  • Remind them of the goal they set when budget planning (does this goal need to change?)
  • Get the person to set themselves a daily or weekly challenge
  • Ensure they are being realistic with their expenditure
  • Make sure that their budget planner allows for spending on outings or items that they want or will enjoy.

Tools

Perhaps a mobile app to track their spending would be useful if they are comfortable with technology.  

Good examples include: 

  1. Money Dashboard 

  1. Monzo 

  1. Starling Bank

There are good resources which explain types of bank accounts and how to open an account:

Citizens Advice Scotland - types of bank account

Money Supermarket - compare bank accounts

Social or environment issues

Revisit any social or environment issue that is restricting their chances of budgeting success:

  • Living in a rural area with limited access to budget shops
  • Limited broadband
  • No internet access
  • No IT skills
  • No cooking skills
  • Pressure from peers to spend money. 

Appointees

Appointees manage someone’s Welfare Benefits or Tax Credits on their behalf. They can apply for benefits online and request information.   

The person you support may have a parent or sibling who is already an Appointee and you could discuss if this is working out or not.  

Some organisations become Appointees if their policy allows. 

An Appointeeship should only be done for a short period of time.   

How to apply

 

Financial guardianship

The person you support may have a financial guardianship arrangement and you can explore how this is working in practice.

Guardianship orders appoint someone to act on someone’s behalf and they cover: 

  • Financial matters only
  • Welfare matters only
  • Or both financial and welfare matters.

Financial Guardianship is only appropriate when someone does not have capacity to make decisions on their own and who cannot appoint a solicitor to act for them. 

Guardianship appointments are usually made by a member of the adult’s family to the Sheriff court.   

Guardianship appointments are usually for a period of  5 – 10 yrs unless there is good reason to grant the appointment for a longer period.

title: Case study
body:
Situation

Jack has lived in supported accommodation for 18 months since leaving care. He wants to move into his own tenancy soon but is worried that he won’t be able to afford the rent. He recently got a job as an apprentice car mechanic and will be attending college one day per week.  

Support provided   

Martha, his support worker, discusses the benefits of budget planning with him. She downloads a budget planner from the website where she helps Jack detail what his income will be when he starts his job and works out his monthly expenditure. On seeing what he has left each month, Jack’s not sure if he will be able to afford his own tenancy.   

Martha works with Jack to see how his income can be increased. She identifies that he will be able to continue claiming housing benefit as he is claiming already which will help with his rent. He will also be able to claim a council tax reduction which will also reduce his outgoings. She helps him identify where savings could be made and explains the benefits of opening a savings account. 

Outcome

Martha will continue to support Jack with budget planning when he gets his tenancy and identify savings on shopping, and other expenses.   

Jack feels more confident that he will be able to afford his own tenancy soon.

title: Key points
body:
• Supporting someone with budgeting skills can help build their financial resilience.
  • Discuss the benefits of budgeting and use online tools such as calculators and budget planners to identify what money is coming in and what money is going out.
  • Discuss how their outgoings could be organised and support them to find ways of maximising their income. 
  • Support someone to stick to their budget and review regularly.

title: Accompanying resources on savings
body:
Looking for a quick resource? Take a look at the following resources which are available from the menu at the top right:

  • Different Savings Schemes - A guide that explains the advantages and disadvantages of different savings schemes.
  • People You Support - The people you support have different priorities, face different barriers and will have individual care support plans.

title: Learn more about savings
body:
Saving money may be a low priority or difficult for people on a low income or receiving benefits. If faced with unemployment, a large fuel bill or an unexpected expense, some people risk getting into debt. This makes it even more difficult to save money.   

Saving money, no matter how small, helps to cushion the blow of unexpected expenses and improves financial resilience.

It is possible to save money at any income level but to do this, people need to:

  • Recognise any barriers to saving
  • Have a savings goal
  • Know what money is coming in and going out
  • Identify ways where savings can be made.

title: Recognise any potential barriers to saving
displayTitle: Recognise any potential barriers to saving
body:
The fear that benefits will be cut  

The reality is that people can save up to £6,000 without it affecting any means-tested benefits. If they save more than that, eligibility to benefits will taper off until savings reach £16,000 when eligibility ends.

People may be in debt 

Some people feel under pressure to buy the latest phone, iPad or television because everyone else has it. Credit cards and buy now pay later schemes encourage this mindset to borrow rather than saving up first.   

The interest rate of savings accounts are generally lower than the interest charged on a debt. However, buying an item on a credit card or using an overdraft rather than saving up is very expensive in the long-term.

title: Case study
body:
Situation

Donna has been living in temporary supported accommodation with her young child since fleeing an abusive partner 3 months ago. She hopes to move to settled accommodation soon. 

Donna discloses to her support worker, Pam, that she has never felt secure with relationships or housing as she has moved 3 times over the past 5 years. Pam takes that opportunity to tell her that having some money to fall back on may help her feel more secure and give her choices.   

Support provided   

Using the Money Advice Service savings calculator Pam identifies that saving £10 per week would give Donna savings of £1000 in two years or £2000 in 4 years. She works with Donna to see if she could afford this by also accessing the Money Advice Service Budget Planner to identify her income and expenditure. Donna can realistically afford to save £8 per week. 

Donna recently opened up a basic bank account with the Royal Bank of Scotland to receive her benefits. One of the savings options Pam discussed with Donna was opening up a savings account with the same bank and transferring money into this weekly. Donna thought this may be a good option but she wants access to her money quickly, especially as she hopes to move to her own tenancy soon. Although the interest rate was slightly lower, Pam identified that a regular savings account may suit her best because she can take out money at short notice whenever she likes.  

Outcome

Pam writes down all the savings options they discussed so that Donna can take time to think about the best option for her. She will raise the subject of saving with Donna again at their next meeting.

title: Key points
body:
• Saving money, no matter how small, helps to cushion the blow of unexpected expenses and improves financial resilience.
  • Recognise the barriers some people may have to save.
  • What is their savings goal? 
  • Ensure the amount being saved is realistic.

title: Have a savings goal (some examples)
body:
Some people may not have a savings goal. It may seem this way anyway, but most people will have a goal for example - to feel safe or happier.  

Understanding the person you are working with will help them identify what their goals are. Try asking questions and fully listen to them when they answer.

title: Know what money is coming in and going out
displayTitle: Know what money is coming in and going out
body: This is fundamental to saving. Knowing what money is coming in and going out will help someone feel more in control of their money and you can help them to create a budget.

title: Identify ways where savings can be made
displayTitle: Identify ways where savings can be made
body:
A budget will enable someone to identify if they have any surplus money for saving. If they saved just £4 every week, they would have £208 after one year. 

The budgeting section has lots of tools and information to help someone budget and identify where possible savings can be made.

title: The difference between saving and investing money
displayTitle: The difference between saving and investing money
body:
Before looking at savings products, its useful to know the difference between saving and investing money.

Select through the following information in the slides:

_items.title: Saving is setting aside money for emergencies or a future purchase
_items.body: Saving is setting aside money for emergencies or a future purchase. It has to be accessed quickly with little or no risk.
_items.strapline: Saving is setting aside money for emergencies or a future purchase

_items.title: Investing is buying assets such as stocks
_items.body:
Investing is buying assets such as stocks, bonds or property with the expectation that the investment will make money long term. 

The higher the risk, the higher the investment growth.
_items.strapline: Investing is buying assets such as stocks

_items.title: Examples
_items.body:
• £2,000 in a savings account at 3% interest would grow to £3,612 in 20 years
  • £2,000 invested in stocks and shares earning 10% per annum would grow to £13,455 in 20 years.

title: Keeping people motivated to save
body: Select the hotspots on the image below to identify some ways to help the person you support stay motivated to save:

_graphic.alt: Adviser helping someone over the phone

_items.title: You could try the following
_items.body:
• Encourage them to save money on the day they get paid or receive their benefits
  • Demonstrate how a set up a standing order to make regular payments. This can be done online or alternatively, you can accompany them to the bank who will set this up for the person
  • Let them know that it's okay to start small. Saving the recommended 3-6 months of income for emergencies can seem impossible. An affordable pot of £500 could make a real difference.

_items.title: How about suggesting
_items.body:
• If they have difficulty saving monthly, suggest they save weekly
  • Remind them of their motivation to save. Is it still the same? If appropriate, ask them how they felt when they had no savings at all
  • Ensure their saving amount is realistic to their budget.

_items.title: You could try to
_items.body:
• Tell them it’s okay to change the amount they save when circumstances change. Better to save less than nothing at all
  • Make sure their budget planner allows for spending on outings or items that they want or will enjoy
  • Ensure the person rewards themselves. For example, if they have spent £40 less that they expected at the end of the month, put £20 in a savings account and use the rest to treat themselves.

_items.title: How about attempting to
_items.body:
• Revisit their budget and identify further savings, for example, changing fuel supplier, changing mobile phone contract. Any savings made could be placed in a savings account
  • Encourage the person you support to save any change into a jar.  When it's full, they can deposit it into their savings account
  • Ask if the person has any unwanted items they could sell to save money. Don't be judgemental as spending money wisely can be subjective.

title: Learn more about planning for later life
displayTitle: Learn more about planning for later life
body:
The relevance of planning for later life applies to everyone. Discussing what people would like to do or what they want in later life may get them to think more about its importance.

For example, people may want to:

  • Have enough money to live on and pay regular outgoing bills 
  • Plan for a holiday that they feel they need
  • Have enough savings to cope with any crisis or emergencies
  • Be debt-free.

title: Pensions
body:
A pension is a long-term savings plan. Savings deposited into a pension scheme are usually eligible for tax relief which means that more money goes into the pension. A person may be eligible or have provision for the pensions below:

  • State Pension (basic state pension or new state pension)
  • Workplace pension
  • NEST pension
  • Personal pension.

title: State pensions
body:
The state pension is paid by the government. When and how much someone receives is based on their National Insurance contributions and their date of birth. Most people will receive their pension from age 66 - 68. 

The new state pension replaced the basic state pension on 6th April 2016. People already in receipt of the basic state pension will continue to receive this. For all new claimants, they will receive the new state pension.

If someone is unable to manage their own financial affairs, there are 3 options available.

New State pension  

Basic State Pension 

  • Based on National Insurance contributions of 10-35 years
  • National Insurance contributions of 35 years will receive full pension of *£168.60 per week.

Part 1:  Basic State Pension

  • Based on national insurance contributions of 11-30 years
  • National Insurance contributions of 30 years will receive full pension of *£125.95 per week. 

Check state pension age 

If someone is within 10 years of state pension age, they can check any contracted out periods by requesting a pension forecast from the DWP. This will tell them how much they are entitled to and highlight any gaps in national insurance contributions.   

They can also seek clarification of any contracted out periods by contacting the HMRC pensions helpline on 08459 150150 and quoting their national insurance number. 

Part 2:  SERPS (State Earnings Related Pension Scheme) 

A UK Government pension arrangement which employees and employers contributed to between 6th April 1978 and 5th April 2002. The scheme aimed to provide a pension related to earnings in addition to the basic state pension. 

SERPS was replaced by the State Second Pension (S2P) in 2002

SERPS and S2P have now closed

It was common for employees who paid full Class 1 NICs between 1978 and 2002 to contract out of SERPS. They did this to pay their contribution directly to their personal pension scheme rather than buy national insurance contributions with it. Benefits are paid through their occupational pension scheme or through a private pension scheme.

title: Make a will
body:
Having a will allows someone to choose who gets their estate after their death. An estate is money, possessions and property. If they don’t have a will, the law will share their estate out in a standard way. This may not be what the person wants, especially if they have a second family or they want to leave something to someone out with their family. A will can also express the person’s funeral arrangements and reduce family distress and disputes at a difficult time.

Many people don’t have a will for a range of reasons.  

Select through the following information in the slides:

_items.title: They don’t have a lot of money or don’t own their house
_items.body: Most people are worth more than they think, especially if they have insurance polices which pay out on death. If the person does have a house a will can help reduce the amount of Inheritance Tax that might be payable on the value of the property and money left behind.
_items.strapline: They don’t have a lot of money or don’t own their house

_items.title: They think their estate will automatically go to their partner
_items.body: The law states that a partner will only inherit if they were married or in a civil partnership with the deceased. No matter how long they have lived together, other partners won’t receive any assets (house), unless they were in joint names.
_items.strapline: They think their estate will automatically go to their partner

_items.title: They think they are too young
_items.body:
No one knows what lies ahead. If someone dies without a will, the law will decide which members of their family will inherit their possessions and estate. It could be divided in a way the person might not have chosen.

People over the age of 18 can create a will.
_items.strapline: They think they are too young

_items.title: They have not got round to it
_items.body: Life is hectic sometimes. Writing a will may not be the top priority for some people but it is an important undertaking, especially if they have a young family to consider.
_items.strapline: They have not got round to it

title: Planning for a funeral
body:
Funeral costs are expensive. Many people worry that when they die that they won’t leave enough money to pay for their funeral. Planning and paying for a funeral before death prevents relatives from covering the costs

Select the hotspots on the image below to identify some ways to plan and pay for a funeral:

_graphic.alt: Adviser helping someone over the phone

_items.title: Pre-paid funeral plan
_items.body:
Planning and paying for the funeral you want at today's prices. The person pays either a lump sum or instalments to the plan provider or a funeral director. 

The plan pays for entitlement to funeral costs as opposed to money. It does not cover everything needed so it's wise to check the details of any plan carefully before buying. 

For example, does it include casket, service, flowers, funeral director fees or cremation fees.

_items.title: Over 50s plan
_items.body:
Money paid to an insurance scheme which only pays out on death. 

Usually, the person has to survive for two years after the plan was taken out. If any payment is missed, the plan won’t pay out. 

It's important to know how much money will be paid out on death.

_items.title: Savings account
_items.body: Saving up to pay for a funeral. This is risky as the person may die before enough money has been built up.

_items.title: Paying from their estate
_items.body: Assets can be sold on the person's death to pay for the funeral.

_items.title: Death in service from an employer
_items.body: Some employers provide a pay-out if the person dies whilst still employed.
_items.strapline: Death in service from an employer

_items.title: Life insurance
_items.body: Pays out a lump sum if someone dies which can be used to pay for a funeral. Payments generally take about one month to be paid out. Further delays can be caused if the death needs investigating.

_items.title: Trade Union
_items.body: If the person is a member of a trade union, professional body or other association, it's possible they will pay a benefit when a member dies.

title: Inheritance Tax
body:
When supporting someone to plan for later life, you can make them aware of inheritance tax to consider how this could affect their family if they die.   

Inheritance tax is a tax on someone’s estate when they die. Their estate is the value of their property, money and possessions. The threshold for paying inheritance tax is £325,000 per person. Inheritance tax is not payable if: 

  • The value of their estate is below the £325,000 threshold 
  • Everything above the £325,000 threshold is left to a spouse, civil partner, a charity or a community amateur sports club.

If these two points don’t apply, inheritance tax is charged at 40% above the £325,000 threshold. For example, if the total estate is valued at £500,000, inheritance tax will be charged on the remaining £175,000 at 40% which is £70,000.

A person you support may be left an inheritance in somebody’s will. The inheritance money could take them over the savings threshold and affect their benefits income. Therefore it is important to look at the options the person may have to avoid their benefits being reduced or stopped. You could support the person to seek specialist advice as this can be complex.

title: Care home costs
body:
If someone moves into a care home in later life, they will have to either pay for the fees in full or make a contribution. How much they get depends on how much capital they have and the type of care home they choose. 

Care Information Scotland has lots of information on this subject including how care needs and financial information is assessed. 

A resource on most common benefits can be downloaded from the ‘Welfare Benefit’ module.

title: Attendance Allowance
body:
This is money for people aged 65 and over who have care needs. Care needs are help with activities of daily living such as getting dressed going to the toilet or having someone to look after them so they don’t hurt themselves.   

It could include help outside the home. It does not matter if no one gives this help, so long as it can be shown that the person needs it. 

It does not matter what type of disability or illness someone has. This includes sight or hearing impairments, or mental health issues such as dementia.

gov.uk/attendance-allowance

title: Planning for incapacity
body:
If someone is unable to manage their own financial affairs, there are 3 options available.

Appointeeship 

Appointees manage someone’s Welfare Benefits or Tax Credits on their behalf. They can apply for benefits online and request information. Appointees are usually close family members.

If you are unsure if the person you support has an Appointee, you can accompany them to their local Jobcentre Plus office. With their permission, the Jobcentre will tell you if they have an Appointee or not.

If someone needs an Appointee but they have no suitable relatives or friends to take on this role, you should contact the local adult support service of the local authority who can take on a corporate appointee role. Corporate Appointees are organisations authorised by the Department of Work and Pensions to manage a vulnerable person's welfare benefits in their best interest.

If the person you support has an Appointee, you can discuss how this is working in practice.   

An Appointeeship should only be done for a short period of time.

Financial Guardianship 

A financial guardianship order appoints someone to act on someone’s behalf. 

They cover:

  • Financial matters only 
  • Welfare matters only 
  • Or both financial and welfare matters.

Financial Guardianship is only appropriate if someone does not have the capacity to make decisions on their own and who cannot appoint a solicitor to act for them. 

Guardianship appointments are usually made by a member of the adult’s family to the Sheriff court.

Guardianship appointments are usually for a period of 5 – 10 years unless there is good reason to grant the appointment for a longer period.

Power of Attorney 

A power of attorney is a legal document which allows someone to plan for the future. It's drawn up when you have the capacity to do so. 

It gives another person, known as the attorney the authority to deal with aspects of their affairs. Such as financial/property matters and/or personal welfare.

title: Case study
body:
Situation

Anna has recently been discharged home from hospital after a lengthy stay. She uses a wheelchair and receives support to live independently in her home.    

Support provided   

Sam, Anna’s support worker, has been supporting Anna with her benefits. At one of her visits, she asks Anna if she has thought about saving for later life. Although she is only 48, Anna expresses her concerns about her long-term health outcomes, not having enough money to live on and who will pay for her funeral if she has no savings. Sam, suggests supporting her to look at practical options to address some of her worries for example, help with saving and looking at options to pay funeral expenses now.   

Sam helps Anna identify that she could save £30 per month and discusses the different types of savings accounts available. She also accesses the information on the website: Money Adviser Service:  Funeral Plans  

Outcome

Anna decides not to take out a funeral plan but to look at a savings account with a mobile app that she could easily access. Sam signposts her to a savings comparison site and will support Anna to choose the best option for her at their next meeting.

title: Key points
body:
• The relevance of planning for later life applies to everyone. Discussing what they want to do or what they want in later life may get them to think about it now or in the future. 
  • Support someone to find out about benefits, pensions, wills, funerals and personal care. This will inform them of what they can expect or need to think about
  • If someone is worried about managing their own financial affairs in later life, make them aware of the options available for example, Appointeeship, Financial Guardianship or Power of Attorney.

title: Workplace pension
body:
Employers must by law offer a workplace pension scheme to all employees earning more than £6,136.  

Each scheme has different rules but generally:

  • Employees must contribute a percentage of their pay to the scheme
  • The employer contributes too – this is what makes a workplace pension attractive
  • Benefits cannot usually be received from the scheme before age 55
  • A pension and a lump sum can be received at retirement
  • There is no tax due on the money paid in however, any pension received in retirement is taxable
  • The scheme may also offer life insurance.

title: Personal pension
body:
Personal pensions are pensions that someone arranges themselves. They usually get tax relief on the money they pay in and can choose how it is invested. It’s usually invested in funds run by professional investment managers.   

  • Pension pot cannot be accessed until at least age 55 

The amount received from a personal pension usually depends on: 

  • How much has been paid in 
  • How the fund’s investments have performed – they can go up as well as down 
  • How the money is taken (eg, pension or lump sum).

title: Debt solutions in 60 seconds
body:
View 'Debt solutions in 60 seconds' part of our 60-second introductions:

Require a transcript of this video? One is available in the resources area of the main menu.

title: Accompanying resources on savings
body:
Looking for a quick resource? Take a look at the following resources which are available from the menu at the top right:

  • Gathering Information Checklist - You could support someone by filling in as much information before referring them to an agency.
  • People You Support - The people you support have different priorities, face different barriers and will have individual care support plans.
  • Debt options for discussion  - A comprehensive list of debt options you can discuss with people.

title: Learn more about debt solutions
body:
Being in debt is stressful for people and can be overwhelming at times. With some support to manage debt people can get back in control 

It is important to be able to: 

  • Discuss the benefits of managing debt with the people you support
  • Know what someone should consider when managing their debt
  • Signpost someone to relevant resources and agencies who offer more specialised advice.

title: Rent arrears
body:
If legal repossession proceedings have started, advise the person you support to contact Shelter Scotland on 0808 800444 or Citizens Advice Scotland for help. If not, you can support them to: 

  • Talk to their landlord
  • Negotiate an affordable payment plan to pay rent arrears
  • Check to see if they are entitled to housing benefit. They could get a backdated payment
  • If they are claiming housing benefit and it does not cover the full rent, they could claim a discretionary housing payment (DHP) to help with the difference. 

Identify the reasons for the payment difficulties, for example, illness, addiction or relationship breakdown issues. 

Assess whether the problem is likely to be for the long or short term and what other types of support are required. 

Contact an adviser at SCOTWRAS (Shelter Scotland), Citizens Advice or other advice agency if: 

  • The person you support does not want or cannot talk to their landlord 
  • Are having difficulty agreeing on an affordable repayment arrangement.

title: Bad debt
body:
If money was used for goods or services that are decreasing in value or no longer valuable. 

  • Selling items bought on credit for much less than you paid for them   
  • Paying for a holiday using a credit card and taking a long time to pay it off 
  • Payday loans and loans from pawn shops have higher interest rates than credit and store cards.

title: The definition of a priority debt
displayTitle: The definition of a priority debt
body:
The person you are working with may not agree with your definition of a priority debt:

You can discuss the consequences of non-payment and address misunderstandings so that the person you support can make an informed choice.

  • Some people may prioritise loans from friends and family because the social or cultural costs of not repaying may be unacceptable
  • They may be intimated or getting harassed by companies, individuals or loan sharks pursing unsecured loans. They are likely to feel pressurised into prioritising these loans.

title: Priority and non-priority debts
body:
Priority debts 

Priority debts should be dealt with before non-priority debts.  

Consequences of non-payment 

The consequences of not paying priority debts are serious. 

Mortgage repayments and loans secured on the home

  • House could be repossessed 
  • Could end up homeless.

 

Rent arrears   

  • Could be evicted 
  • Legal action can be taken to recover rent arrears.   
  • Could end up homeless. 

Secured loans taken against the value of your home 

  • House could be repossessed 

     

  • Could end up homeless. 

Fuel debts

  • Fuel is cut off 
  • Expensive pre-payment meter installed  
  • Court action taken to recover amount due
  • Goods can be taken from home 
  • Money can be taken from wages or benefits at source 
  • Money can be taken from bank account.

title: Case study
body:
Situation

Robert has alcohol-related brain damage and lives in supported accommodation. He lost his job 6 months ago and has run up debts. He owes his credit card over £4000. He also borrowed £500 from a doorstep lender with high weekly payments. 

As the collection agent turned up at his home each week to collect the money, he was too scared to explain that the payments were unaffordable, so he took payday loans to cover the payments. 

Support provided   

Robert has twice-weekly meetings with John, his support worker, who is working with him to stabilise his situation. John understands that Robert’s financial wellbeing will aid his recovery which is an outcome of his support plan.   

During a casual chat, John asks Robert if he has enough money to live on each week. Robert’s hesitant answer prompted John to ask additional questions and over a couple of weeks, Robert disclosed the scale of his debts. 

John gathered information about Roberts debts for example, who money owed to, address, principle debt, debt outstanding and interest rate. He was able to identify that Robert’s debts were non-priority debts. 

Seeking Roberts permission, John referred and accompanied him to his local Citizens Advice Bureau where he passed over this information.  

Outcome

The CAB helped Robert create a budget plan and maximise his income before contacting his creditors to agree a more realistic payment and term. 

John’s casual approach and strong communication skills identified Robert’s debt problem. His knowledge of priority and non-priority debts and information gathering prepared Robert for an interview with a specialist money adviser who contacted the agencies to negotiate more realistic payments and terms. 

John will continue to support Robert which his payments, revisiting his budget plan were necessary.

title: Key points
body:
• Debt is stressful and controls what someone can and can’t do. Managing debt can help put someone back in control. 
  • Support someone to identify their debts and categorise into priority and non-priority debts.
  • Help people to create budget plans. 
  • Be aware of debt options available, signposting people to relevant resources or agencies who offer more specialised advice. 
  • Motivate people to stay on track and review any repayment plan.

View 'Borrowing in 60 seconds' part of our 60-second introductions:

title: Accompanying resources on borrowing
body:
Looking for a quick resource? Take a look at the following resources which are available from the menu at the top right:

  • Alternatives to borrowing - If someone wants to borrow money there may be possible alternatives.
  • People You Support - The people you support have different priorities, face different barriers and will have individual care support plans.
  • Advantages and disadvantages to different types of borrowing - There are many options to borrowing money, with some options better than others.
  • Checklist for discussions around borrowing - A useful checklist for discussions around borrowing money.

title: Learn more about borrowing
body:
Many people borrow money. 

It’s usually when their income is less than their outgoings or their savings are not enough to pay for large items like a car or home improvements.

People also borrow money to cover the cost of life change events expenses such as: 

  • Loss of job
  • Illness
  • Caring for a sick or elderly relative
  • The birth of a child
  • Emergency needs due to a crisis.

Some of these events are uncontrollable and borrowing money to pay for food, bills or pay off existing debts may seem the only option for some people. Addiction issues or feeling pressured to buy Christmas presents can add to the financial pressures some people face.

title: Understanding someone’s full financial and personal situation
displayTitle: Understanding someone’s full financial and personal situation
body:
Borrowing money requires careful consideration and budget planning. Understanding someone’s full financial and personal situation is vital before giving any information on borrowing.

Select through the following information in the slides:

_items.title: Care leavers
_items.body: Care leavers who need support to live independently who may find it difficult to manage their money and pay bills.

_items.title: People with mental health issues
_items.body: People with mental health issues, for example, a person spending their weekly budget in one day during a manic episode.

_items.title: People with learning or physical disabilities
_items.body: People with learning or physical disabilities who may struggle to manage their budget, get into debt and borrow money from high-interest rate lenders to pay the debt.
_items.strapline: People with learning or physical disabilities

_items.title: Recovering from alcohol or drug addiction
_items.body: Recovering from alcohol or drug addiction and may struggle to manage their money and who may have borrowed money in the past to fuel their addiction.
_items.strapline: Recovering from alcohol or drug addiction

_items.title: Experienced a crisis
_items.body: Experienced a crisis including homelessness, for example, borrowing money to stabilise their immediate situation.

title: Borrowing options
body:
There are many options to borrow money, with some options cheaper than others. People with low credit scores and poor credit history will generally not be eligible for low-interest rates loans.   

With limited options, some people may choose a high-interest rate product from a doorstep lender or loan shark.   

It's useful to know your credit score and how this can be improved before looking at borrowing options.

Check-your-credit-score

Note: you should check out our resource on the advantages and disadvantages of different types of borrowing. It's available via the main menu.

title: Mobile phones & iPads
body:
Taking out a contract with a mobile phone provider for a mobile phone or iPad is still a loan. People should be advised to shop around for the best deal and only take the data package they need. 

Make them aware of the following:

  • They will generally be tied into a two-year contract to cover the cost of the phone or iPad 
  • If the contract is cancelled before the contract end date, the outstanding payments must be paid as a lump sum
  • If phone or iPad is lost or stolen (unless its insured), the monthly fee still needs to be paid until the contract ends (in addition to buying a replacement)
  • It's easy to go over the data limit of the contract.

title: Buying a house
body:
Almost everyone will need to borrow money to buy a house. They will probably need a mortgage which is the term used to describe a secured loan on a property. In Scotland, the correct name is a secured loan. However, the term ‘mortgage’ is generally used.

All mortgages share the same basic characteristics:

  • The lender has security over the borrower’s home and/or any other property which offers the lender enough security for the loan
  • Interest is charged on the loan
  • The borrower agrees to repay instalments with interest over a fixed period.

title: The main mortgage types
body:
Capital repayment 

The borrower pays part capital and part interest on the loan until the capital and the interest are paid off. 

Interest only 

The borrower only makes payments for the interest. The borrower takes out a life insurance policy or other savings plan and pays monthly premiums. The policy produces a lump sum to pay off the mortgage. 

Some lenders may allow borrowers to take out interest-only mortgages without a plan or investment to repay the capital. There are obvious risks attached to this and money advice will be needed. 

Most lenders will only issue this type of mortgage if the borrower has a large enough deposit and arrangements in place to repay the loan when the mortgage term ends. Borrowers may find that the long term saving plan (endowment policy, shares, investment bonds or pension) is not enough to pay off the amount borrowed(capital). Therefore, there are risks attached to this and money advice will be needed. 

Combination  issues

It is possible to obtain mortgages which combine these types. Flexible mortgages, which can include payment breaks and/or increases or decreases in monthly payments, are available. 

Different interest rates are available and other terms may vary.

title: Case study
body:
Situation

Saeed lives in supported accommodation with minimal to no savings. He mentions to Janice, his support worker, that he wants to buy a new mobile phone. Having already supported Saeed to set up a budget plan to manage his debts, she suggested revisiting this plan to identify ways that he could afford a phone.  

Support provided   

Janice makes Saeed aware that as he has no savings to buy a new phone now, he will have to obtain credit which is just like borrowing money. Saeed is unwilling to save to buy his phone outright and so they identify together that he could afford a new phone if his monthly payment remained the same. 

Janice makes him aware that if his existing contract is cancelled before the contract end date, the outstanding payments must be paid as a lump sum which he would be unable to afford on top of his monthly contract fee.  

Outcome

As Saeed has two months left on his existing contract, he agrees to wait until his exiting contract runs out, when Janice will support him to shop around for the best deal and accompany him to the phone shops if he wants.

title: Key points
body:
• Borrowing money requires careful consideration and budget planning. 
  • Know why someone wants to borrow money and what their barriers are.
  • Explain how interest and APR rates are calculated to help someone choose the best borrowing option.
  • Identify alternatives to borrowing, for example, grants, income maximisation and budgeting skills.
  • Offer on-going support to maintain payments.

title: Not having a bank account
body:
Reasons for this may include: 

  • Don’t know how to open a bank account (If the person has a computer and internet access, you can show them how to apply online. Alternatively, you could support them by going into the bank)
  • Because they are not allowed to open an account due to eligibility or lack of ID (Find out why they can’t open a bank account. It may be because of outstanding debt. If they are getting tax credits or Universal Credit, they may be eligible to join the government’s Help to Save scheme and get back an extra 50p for every £1 they save).

Note: to expand further on the range of potential barriers to saving for the people you support, access our 'People You Support' guide in the menu.

title: Do they want:
body:
• To feel better or happier? (Having a financial safety net can help mental and physical wellbeing. It allows someone to have choices and feel more in control of their life)
  • A home? (They may want to save for a rental deposit or a deposit to buy their own home)
  • A new phone or iPad? (Saving up in advance can avoid debt and the sense of achievement when they reach their saving goal can be very rewarding)
  • To be more financially independent? (They may want to stop relying on other people or family to help them pay for essentials or emergencies) 
  • To have money to spend on both needs and wants?
  • To not be afraid? (For example, having enough money to pay off debts or move to a safer environment)
  • A financial safety net in case of emergencies? (For example, the birth of a child, broken boiler or car repair)
  • Enough money to live on in later life? (Most people’s income will reduce in later life. Living on a pension will be easier if they have some savings to fall back on).

title: Beware of scamming
body:
People saving up money for later life should be aware of scams. This is often where criminals use the internet to con people into giving them money or personal information. 

Scammers can create fake websites which look like bank websites or government sites.  

Advise them to:

  • Delete emails from unrecognised senders
  • Never update account or security information online
  • If the email is from an organisation, phone the organisation directly using the telephone number on their official website
  • Not follow a link as it will usually direct to an invalid website starting with http rather than https. If unsure, access the correct website and call the organisation directly.

Contact the police immediately if you suspect the person you support has been the victim of a scam.

title: Writing a will
body:
There are 3 ways to write a will: 

Use a solicitor 

The most expensive option but the recommended option. It's best if affairs are complex for example, former partners and children. Approximate costs vary between £150 and £300  

Use a will writing service

Approximate cost is £75 however, the person writing the will may not be legally qualified. 

Do it yourself 

This method is not recommended if the person’s affairs are complex. It is the cheapest option though with templates available online to download for £10 approximately. It would also be written on blank paper.

A will is valid if it: 

  • Says how the estate should be shared out when the person dies
  • Was made when the person was able to make their own decisions and not put under pressure about who to leave things to
  • Is signed and dated by the person in the presence of two independent adult witnesses. It must then be signed by the two witnesses in the person’s presence. The witnesses can’t be people who are going to inherit anything from the person for example, a husband/wife or civil partner.

title: National insurance contributions
body:
National Insurance contributions are a tax on earnings and paid by employees and employers. They are used to fund:

  • The state pension
  • The NHS
  • Unemployment benefit
  • Sickness and disability allowances.

There are 4 classes of national insurance contributions (NIC).

Select through the following information in the slides:

_items.title: Class 1 National Insurance contributions
_items.body: These are paid by people who work for an employer. The employer takes the national insurance contribution off wages or salary before paying the employee. The employer also has to pay national insurance contributions on the employee’s earnings.

_items.title: Class 2 National Insurance contributions
_items.body: You pay class 2 national insurance contributions if you are self-employed. The HMRC collect these contributions through the self-assessment system.

_items.title: Class 3 National Insurance contributions
_items.body:
If someone is not eligible to pay class 1 or class 2 national insurance contributions and they don’t receive National Insurance credits, their rights can be protected to some state benefits by paying class 3 national insurance contributions. These are also known as voluntary contributions.   

For 2019/20, the rate of class 3 national insurance contributions is £15 per week

_items.title: Class 4 National Insurance contributions
_items.body: Class 4 national insurance contributions are paid by self-employed people. They are paid in addition to class 2 national insurance contributions but Class 4 national insurance contributions don’t count towards any state benefits. People are only liable to pay class 4 national insurance benefits if their profits are over a certain level.

title: Component title
body:
If someone is not working and claiming benefits because they are ill or caring for someone, they may be able to get Class 1 or Class 3 national insurance credits to count towards their state pension.

If the above does not apply, there are 3 options for securing a state pension:

  • Make voluntary contributions to cover any gaps when they weren’t working or getting credits
  • Use their current partner or former partner’s national insurance record to claim
  • Defer your state pension age.  

The National Insurance helpline is 0300 200 3500 for more information.

title: Interest and APR rates
body:
Borrowing money incurs interest and fees. The cost of the loan will always be more than the amount borrowed. Understanding how interest and APR rates are calculated will help someone choose the best borrowing option.

Interest % 

Most lenders will charge interest on the loan.   

Example: 

Bank loan 

  • £1000 borrowed over two years with a fixed interest rate of 5% per annum. 
  • Interest is £50 per year 
  • Cost of loan with interest over two years is £1100. £48.83 per month 
  • If loan was paid over 12 months, cost of loan would be £1050. £87.50 per month 
  • Support someone to determine if the loan repayments are affordable and will continue to be affordable. Saving up for the item is also an option. 

APR %

APR stands for Annual Percentage Rate.

The APR is the interest on the loan plus other charges payable. 

Example: 

APR may be 8% 

This means that the charges applicable to the loan are 3%. 

When comparing loans, compare the APR rates. This is because some companies offer a low-interest rate but when fees are added, the APR rate increases. This makes the total cost of the loan more expensive.

Lenders must state what their APR is before an agreement is signed.

Interest-free loans are only interest-free if they are repaid within the agreed time period. If not, the interest rate added to the loan is extremely high. For example, an Ipad from Curry’s costs £299.00. If the balance is paid at the end of 12 months, there is no interest to pay. If not, the APR rate could be as much as 24.9% which increases the loan by 25% per year.

Watch out for ‘payment holiday’ deals. Taking a payment holiday extends the term of the loan and adds will add more interest to the loan. It could also go against your credit history and make future borrowing more difficult.

Request a repayment schedule showing the total cost of the loan before agreeing to anything.

title: Know the barriers to borrowing that people face
displayTitle: Know the barriers to borrowing that people face
body:
• They may have no bank account 
  • Be unemployed 
  • Have difficulty getting identification documents 
  • Have limited or no financial literacy
  • Have no credit score or bad credit history
  • Be vulnerable
  • Have an appointee or guardianship arrangement
  • Have incapacity issues.  

Mental capacity to take out a loan 

In Scotland, on the balance of probabilities if it can be shown that the borrower lacked the capacity to enter into a contract, then the contract is void.

title: Identify why a person wants to borrow money
displayTitle: Identify why a person wants to borrow money
body:
Ask the person you are supporting to consider the following: 

  • Why do they want to borrow money?
  • Do they need to borrow money?
  • Could they save and buy the item later or do without it?
  • Do they have savings which they can use instead? 

These are all criminal offences and should be reported to the police.   

If someone is looking to borrow money due to a sudden drop in income which has left them unable to pay for basic essentials, be aware that they may be the victim of financial abuse.  

This might include: 

  • Someone collecting and stealing benefit payments
  • Someone borrowing money and not paying it back
  • Fallen victim to a fraud or scam.

title: There are two types of debt
displayTitle: There are two types of debt

title: Priority and non-priority debts
body:
Non-priority debts 

Failing to pay non-priority debts is less serious than not paying a priority debt.  

Consequences of non-payment 

The consequences of not paying non-priority debts.

  • Credit card debts  
  • Hire Purchase agreements (HP)  
  • Unsecured bank loans - loans that are not secured against Client's property  
  • Loans from friends and family.
  • Creditors may sue for money that is owed which could result in a court judgement against the person 
  • Credit rating may be affected 
  • Some lenders may be intimidating or threaten violence.

title: Good debt
body:
If money was used to invest in something that is increasing in value which is higher than the cost of the credit.

  • Low rate mortgage on a property which has increased in value by more than the mortgage repayments  
  • Purchasing a car using credit is arguably a good debt because although it depreciates in value, it is still an ‘investment’ 
  • A student loan because education improves an individual’s future employment prospects.

title: Maximise your income
body:
There are organisations in Scotland who can offer an income maximisation service. 

They can:

  • Complete checks for benefit entitlement
  • Complete benefits forms
  • Can provide or refer for specialist advice on debt and fuel poverty
  • Check tax issues for example, allowances and how much should be paid. 

Other ideas to increase income: 

  • If able to work, look for a job or second job
  • Sell unwanted goods
  • Rent out a room (seek the permission of a landlord if the accommodation is rented).

 

Knowing what is coming in and what is going out will help avoid further debt. A budget plan can spot areas where spending can be reduced to pay off debt. 

Note: visit the topic ‘budgeting’ to find out how to create a budget plan.

title: Debt crisis
body:
As early as possible, identify if someone you support has a debt crisis:  

Examples: 

  • They don’t feel safe (they may be at risk of violence or intimidation due to an outstanding debt)
  • They have a decree for eviction outstanding due to non-payment of rent
  • Their gas or electric is at risk of being cut off
  • They have no money for food. 

If a person is in crisis, recognise when to refer them for specialist money or housing advice.  

A useful tool to identify debt levels and tips to reduce debt and get back on track with finances is moneyadviceservice.org.uk/debt-test

title: Unsafe credit or debt and scamming
displayTitle: Unsafe credit or debt and scamming
body:
For some people who have been refused a loan from a bank, their only option for borrowing money may be through an illegal money lender, often referred to as a loan shark. 

Loansharks charge extremely high rates of interest and if payments are missed, interest can be increased making their debt even more. 

For others, their debt may as a result of falling victim to a scam. For example, their personal identity has been stolen to purchase goods. 

Scams come in many forms and are all designed to get someone’s money.

Citizens Advice Scotland is a good resource which explains what to do if the person you support has fallen victim of identity fraud or scamming.
